Award.AwardTitle: TC: Small: Collaborative Research: Implications of Fully Homomorphic Encryption

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Recently, Gentry and others have established the feasibility of constructing fully homomorphic encryption schemes. Briefly, a fully homomorphic encryption (FHE) scheme is one that allows a third-party who has ciphertexts of several messages to construct---without knowing the decryption key---a new ciphertext that corresponds to an arbitrary efficiently computable function applied to the original messages. Fully homomorphic encryption has the potential to allow disparate organizations to compute basic functions on their pooled data-sets without revealing such data to each other. It is thus an ultimate solution for implementing ``need-to-know'' privacy.

Until Gentry's discovery, few researchers believed that FHE could be constructed. As a result, the concept has not been well-studied despite its clear potential to solve important tasks in a privacy-preserving manner. In particular, the basic relationship between FHE and traditional public-key cryptography remains unclear. The goals of this research project are to formalize this relationship, to build notions of FHE that satisfy stronger security guarantees such as security even when the adversary has access to a restricted decryption oracle, and to potentially use these stronger security guarantees to apply FHE in secure and privacy preserving computation.

To ensure the broader impact of the research, this project includes mentoring of students at all levels from undergraduate to post-doctoral and outreach activities to traditionally under-represented students and K-12 students. Research from this project will be disseminated through presentations and publications in conferences, journals and on the Internet.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this research project was to clarify the relationship between fully-homomorphic encryption (FHE) and other cryptographic primitives. In particular, we aimed to show how to build chosen ciphertext-secure (CCA2) encryption from FHE, we aimed to build stronger notions of FHE, and we aimed to understand the role of FHE in secure multiparty computation.  During the research, we also extended our focus to consider the relationship between other notions of encryption as well as the relationships between indistinguishability obfuscation (iO) and other primitives.  

In the end, we did not resolve our main question concerning a construction of CCA2 from FHE.  However, we were able to advance the state-of-the-art in the theory of encryption by constructing various notions of encryption from weaker primitives than previously known.  We were able to show a black-box proof of knowledge of plaintext for an FHE scheme and this resulted in a construction of a secure computation protocol from Threshold-FHE.  We studied stronger notions of encryption such as Bounded Key Dependent Message-secure (KDM-secure, and CCA2-KDM-secure) encryption and showed how to construct them from weaker primitives (primitives that do not imply collision-resistant hashing).  We were able to construct intermediate notions of adaptively-secure non-malleable encryption from weaker primitives (and this work lead to even stronger constructions by other researchers). We  identified key bottlenecks in the construction of iO schemes from graded encoding schemes.  The project resulted in several publications on these topics, and resulted in 1 PhD thesis for one of the students supported by the project (who now works in the Google security group).
